answer_html: \((X \cap Y)^c=X^c \cup Y^c\) Here the c indicates the complement of the set.
answer_latex: $(X \cap Y)^c=X^c \cup Y^c$ Here the c indicates the complement of the set.
hints_html: De Morgan’s laws are about the intersections, unions, and complements of sets.
hints_latex:
De Morgan's laws are about the intersections, unions, and complements of
sets.
hints_raw: De Morgan's laws are about the intersections, unions, and complements of sets.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
De Morgan’s laws are, for sets \(X, Y \subseteq Z\) the following.

\[\begin{aligned} (X \cup Y)^c = X^c \cap Y^c\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} (X \cap Y)^c = X^c \cup Y^c\end{aligned}\]

Here the c indicates the complement of the set.
sols_raw:
De Morgan's laws are, for sets <math>X, Y \subseteq Z</math> the following.

:<math>(X \cup Y)^c = X^c \cap Y^c</math>

and

:<math>(X \cap Y)^c = X^c \cup Y^c</math>

Here the c indicates the complement of the set.
statement_html: State De Morgan’s laws (in the context of sets).

statement_raw: State De Morgan's laws (in the context of sets).
